question: Posted By Ken on August 08, 1998 at 17:05:59:I'm a 33 year old who has just suffered his third MI in two years.  After this last attack, I had two angioplasties and two stents.  Consequently, I was placed on Plavix (along with several other medications that I was already taking).My question:  Are there any indications of Plavix causing hyperglycemia in insulin-dependent Type I diabetics?  For me, taking Plavix in the morning caused a precipitous rise in my blood glucose levels that required very large amounts of insulin and at least four hours in order to bring to acceptable levels.My suspicion of Plavix is due to my having been a diabetic for 15 years and knowing my body and my symptoms very well.  Plavix was the only new drug that I was taking in the morning.  My endocrinologist doesn't think it should cause a problem, but I'm not so sure.For the last three days, however, I have been waiting until evening (with cardiologist's permission) to take my Plavix.  By evening my blood sugar levels are better under control and I have a larger amount of insulin already at work in my body.  The Plavix is only causing a very small rise in blood sugar levels when I take it at evening like this.I hope I'm not just confusing cause-effect with coincidence.  If anyone knows of any studies, or anecdotal evidence, or pharmacological reasons, for this hyperglycemia, please post a response.Thanks.
title: Plavix and diabetes
